sen.e: Starting in the Azuchi-Momoyama Period, Osaka began to develop, and Kyoto is believed to have grown into a city of 300,000, with spread of residential areas in the Kamigyo and Shimogyo areas.

It is considered that in the Azuchi-Momoyama Period, Osaka began to develop, while Kyoto, where the two separated dwelling areas, Kamigyo and Shimogyo, were unified through the gradual development of the contiguous area in between, had grown into a city of some 300,000 people.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ってすぐの1609年に日本へ漂流したロドリゴ・デ・ビベロは、京都の人口を30～40万人、大坂の人口を20万人、江戸の人口を15万人と伝えている。
sen.e: According to Rodrigo de Vivero y Velasco who was washed ashore on a coast of Japan in 1609, in the early years of the Edo Period, Kyoto had population from 300 to 400 thousand, Osaka had 200,000 and Edo had 150,000.

According to Rodrigo de Vivero y Velasco who drifted down to a coast of Japan in 1609, at the beginning of the Edo period, the population in Kyoto was between 300,000 and 400,000, while 200,000 in Osaka and 150,000 in Edo.

sen.e: Despite fluctuations by time of year, the populations of the three major cities of the Edo Period are estimated at more than one million for Edo at its peak and at 400,000 each for Kyoto and Osaka.

sen.e: Besides these three cities, the cities of Kanazawa and Nagoya are believed to have had populations in the scale of 100,000 at most, with Nagasaki, Sakai and Kagoshima having population of more than 60,000 each and other leading castle towns having populations of roughly 50,000 each.

Besides these three cities, the estimated population was 100,000 at the highest in Kanazawa and in Nagoya and more than 60,000 in Nagasaki City, Sakai City and Kagoshima City, respectively, while the population of any of other leading castle towns was approximately 50,000.

sen.j: 幕藩体制維持のため各藩の拠点は一箇所の城下町に固定化され、更に領外への経済圏の自由な拡大が制約されたため、全国的な拠点とされた三都との間に格差が生じたと考えられる。
sen.e: The divide with the three major cities of national stature is believed to be due to shogunate order under which each feudal domain had only a single castle town and restrictions were imposed on economic activities extending beyond the sphere of the domain.

Such a difference between the three major cities positioned as national centers and the rest of the cities is believed to have been deliberately brought about by the bakufu's policy to secure the shogunate system, by concentrating the center of each domain into a single castle town, and by restricting the free economic expansion of the city beyond the sphere of the domain.

sen.e: The center of culture and industry, the city of Kyo had been the capital of the country since Heian-kyo and was the location of the Imperial Court and the home of a number of leading Buddhist sects, despite setbacks in the Onin War, serving as the leading city in academic study, arts and religion at that time.

sen.e: In particular, the three cities gave birth to distinctive cultures, with Kyo as center of Kanei culture, Osaka the center of Genroku culture and Edo the center of Kasei culture, all of which flourished in reflection of the times and conditions of the respective eras.

sen.j: なお、江戸時代後期の儒学者で江戸や大坂に住んだこともある広瀬旭荘（広瀬淡窓の弟）は、『九桂草堂随筆』という随筆の中で「京の人は細なり。大坂の人は貪なり。江戸の人は夸なり……是三都人気の異る所以なり」と述べていくつか事例を挙げながら三都の比較を試みている。
sen.e: Gyokuzo HIROSE (younger brother of Taso HIROSE), a Confucian scholar of the latter Edo Period who had lived in Edo and Osaka, describes the temperaments of the people of the three great cities in his compendium, Kyukeisodou Zuihitsu, saying that "the people of Kyo are highly sensitive, the people of Osaka are voracious and the people of Edo are proud," comparing the three cities through examples.
